column1: 720>720 Degree>Atari Games>Atari Games>1986>Sports/Skateboarding>AAMA - Green (Suitable For All Ages)>1 Player>4.4>720? is a 1- or 2-player (alternating) skateboard themed game with both competitive and street-style skating action. The player portrays the skater who performs skate maneuvers for points and competes in skate parks for medals. The action takes place in a Skate City where all surfaces are skateable. Players can choose where they want to skate in the city
column2: and which skate parks they want to enter
column3: making each new game a different experience.[-LF-]At the start of each game
column4: players can select one of two play modes. A training game is available for beginning players. In this game
column5: there are numerous playing hints and messages
column6: and the add-a-coin feature is disabled. Experienced players can start off by skating to a higher platform. Fewer game hints are given in this mode
column7: and the add-a-coin feature is offered.[-LF-]Game play starts with the player in the middle of Skate City. Using a new rotary control and a jump and a Kick button
column8: players maneuver around the city trying to score points by performing skillful skate moves. At various score thresholds
column9: skate park tickets are rewarded. These tickets allow entry into one of the skate parks
column10: where players compete against the clock for gold
column11: silver or bronze medals.[-LF-]The player's main objective is to compete in as many skate parks as possible. In the city streets
column12: players have a limited amount of time to win entry tickets and make their way to a skate park. In addition
column13: there are numerous city hazards which must be avoided such as BMX riders
column14: cars
column15: Frisbee throwers
column16: and other gangs. To guide the player in the city
column17: players find map areas in streets which momentarily display the layout of the city and the location of the skate parks.[-LF-]In 720? there are ten class levels which determine the degree of difficulty in the skate parks and the timer in the streets. Players select the class level in which they want to compete. For instance
column18: at the start of each game
column19: there are four unique skate parks which are located in the outskirts of the city. Each park is a different class ranging from class 1 difficulty
column20: which is the easiest
column21: to class 4 difficulty
column22: the hardest.[-LF-]In 720? players can compete in over 20 different skate parks. Each one requires unique skill moves to qualify for a medal. There are variations of a half-pipe ramp
column23: a downhill; a slalom and a jump park. Each skate park has a distinct music score of its own
column24: creating a different mood for players.[-LF-]In the skate parks
column25: cash prizes arc awarded to players that qualify for a medal. After each skate park competition
column26: the game continues back in the city for more street-style skating. Players can use their cash winnings to buy equipment from various skate shops which are located throughout the city. Skating equipment helps players perform better moves. Boards give faster speed. Helmets allow more risk-taking for successful maneuvers. Pads give faster recovery from falls. Shoes provide more height on jumps and quicker starts. As a reference for locating skate shops and park entrances
column27: players find map areas throughout the city by skating over a map. A layout of the city is momentarily displayed when players skate over a map.[-LF-]In 720? a game ends only when players run out of time in the city. When the timer is running low
column28: a SKATE OR DIE message appears along with a warning in speech. When the timer runs out
column29: killer-bees appear as a final warning. If the player is killed by the bees before entering a skate park
column30: the game is over. Using the add-a-coin feature
column31: players can continue where they left off. 720? has an operator option to select maximum number of add-a-coins allowed. By using the add-a-coin
column32: players can keep any special skate equipment they have acquired in the previous game
column33: as well as all accumulated cash

column1: batsugun>Batsugun>Toaplan>Toaplan>1993>Shoot-'Em-Up>AAMA - Green (Suitable For All Ages)>1-2 Players>4.4>"Batsugun (バツグン Batsugun?) is a vertically scrolling shoot 'em up video game created by the now-defunct Japanese game developer Toaplan. The title translates to ""exceptional"" or ""extraordinary"".Originally developed for the arcade
column2: Batsugun was first released in 1993. A second edition named Batsugun Special Version was shown at the AOU (Arcade Operators Union) show in Japan but was never released as Toaplan slid into bankruptcy. After Toaplan's bankruptcy
column3: the Special Version appeared on the secondhand market. The two revisions were released on the Sega Saturn in 1996 as a single package coded by Toaplan offshoot Gazelle.Heralded by some as the first ""manic shooter""
column4: Batsugun's development involved employees who would go on to form and work at Cave and continue to work in this subgenre. This includes the game's chief programmer Tsuneki Ikeda. Batsugun saw an evolution in the use of complex enemy wave and bullet patterns
column5: and player firepower and hit-box.The Special Edition featured a number of changes including a smaller hitbox
column6: a shield protecting the player from one hit
column7: more powerful bombs
column8: new scoring items
column9: and the addition of multiple game rounds or loops of increasing difficulty.The Saturn releases are nearly the same but differ from the arcade versions in subtle ways
column10: including rearranged music and lack of slowdown in some cases which can make the game more difficult.">

column3:

bloodstm>Blood Storm>Strata>Incredible Technologies>1994>Fighter>AAMA - Yellow (Animated Violence Mild)>1-2 Players>3.9>The Mega War, fought centuries ago, left the earth in global ruins.  Thedestructive nuclear horrors unleashed upon the planet and its populationcreated uncountable amounts of death and devastation.  In the wake of thissweeping havoc arose the planet itself to retaliate against the violenceforced upon it.  Polar shifts and massive earthquakes swallowed entirecontinents.  From seething seas and walls of water arose angry volcanoes,spewing flame and death into the sky.  Hungry fires, searing blizzards, andbrutal storms ran rampant across the planet's surface for years, in an attemptto wash away the man-made horrors that it was forced to endure. At last the earth settled into a new pattern, starting to find somesemblance of balance and peace.  The global changes had left a much harsherplanet, and the remaining life forms adapted slowly to the new environment.The Earth's land masses, altered by man-made weaponry and ended throughelemental means, had evolved into ten isolated provinces.  The remainingpopulations within these new provinces found life difficult at first, butslowly evolution and natural selection allowed the human race to adapt andonce again gain control of their destiny.  Some of the provinces had strongnatural forces, exposed through the abrupt upheaval, and the resourcefulpost-humans began to master these new powers.  Other provinces continued todevelop through the use of science and technology, creating elaborate lifesupport systems and protection against the harsh environments. As the years progressed, eight of the provinces began to communicate andtrade together.  An alliance was formed and a global quasi-government wasestablished.  The social structure evolved into a mixture of medievalpractices, hybrid technology, and barbarism and barter. Centuries have passed and the present day Earth finds mankind again at thebrink of savagery and destruction.  Life is now a series of hardships,deceptions, and lies for the members of the Provincial Alliance.  The frozentundra of Polaria and the volcanic Scorch are very close to all out war,halted only by the desolate, radioactive Death Zone that separates them.  TheDeath Zone, once a founding member of the Planet Alliance, has remained silentfor almost two centuries, hiding behind the mysterious and deadly red miststhat define its borders.  Obsel, the desert province, has been taken over bydesperate and brutal female terrorists.  The Ebony Coast, known for its tradeand bartering systems, is now led by a mysterious and greedy leader whom noone trusts, yet all must tolerate.  The people of Cyberia, a land inhabitableonly through technological means, have re-engineered their population, and arelosing their humanity to the machine. With tensions running high, the Planet Alliance is beginning to falter andthe provinces are no longer considered allies.  And now the High Emperor, theone guiding force that all provinces had agreed to abide by, has beenmysteriously and horribly murdered. The ancient Provincial Agreement declares that a new ruler must be chosenthrough combat between the rulers of each province.  Each province will comeprepared for battle with their own Gauntlet of Ascension, a gloved weapon thatonly those in power may don.  These ancient gauntlets are treasured andrevered by their people, for they are the foremost symbol of power and honoreach province can have. But it is painfully clear that this tournament will not have the honor ofprevious BloodStorm contests.  There have even been rumors that the combatantswill bring back the Sunder Attack, a brutal combat move that separated theopponent's legs from his body without killing him.  This horrible andhumiliating maneuver has never been officially banned from the BloodStormcontest, yet it is so brutal and degrading that no honorable combatant hasused it for centuries.  However, these champions from radically differentprovinces are blind to the mysterious evil that surrounds the High Emperor'sdeath, and instead only see their opportunity for personal gain, provincialexpansion, or race domination and will do anything to achieve their goals.  The BloodStorm is about to begin!>
bloodwar>Blood Warrior>Kaneko>Kaneko>1994>Fighter>AAMA - Red (Animated Violence Strong)>1-2 Players>4.1>The gameplay of Blood Warrior is quite similar to many of the 2D fighting games of the same era. column5: and the score value stops when the ball first hits a pin. If the player throws a strike he receives that score value. If he gets a spare he gets half the original value. If he fails to convert the spare then he gets 1 point for each pin that he did knock down. Scores can go up to nearly 10
column6: 000 points![-LF-]* In 'BlackJack' each player gets up to 3 throws to attempt to knock down 21 pins. Each time the full rack of ten pins is set. All pins knocked down by all players in one frame are added to the pot. The player who gets closest to 21 without going over gets all the points in the pot
column7: and the pot is cleared to zero for the next frame. If a player gets 21 exactly then he gets twice the value in the pot. If 2 or more players tie in a frame they each get the points from the pot (or twice the points if they each have 21). Players who do not get closest to 21 or who bust (go over 21) get no points for the frame. Knocking down one pin scores as an ace
column8: and is worth one or eleven
column9: depending on what the player needs. his game is best played by several players together. The more players

column5: the sweeping radar display shows a dot for the enemy's location

column7: it will be shown on the screen below and will be accompanied by the message ENEMY IN RANGE.[-LF-]Occasionally the flying saucer appears on the screen. It is a harmless observer to the battle and will not destroy the enemy or player. Its position is never shown on the radar

challeng>Challenger>Game Plan>Centuri>1981>Shoot-'Em-Up>AAMA - Green (Suitable For All Ages)>1-2 Players>3.9>"CHALLENGER is the newest video game to be introduced by Centuri. With its vivid colors and lively setting
column2: it is sure to lure the most ardent player into game action.[-LF-]The game consists of 16 sectors (rounds) of play. Sector 1 begins with Large Energy Rings floating randomly across the screen. The Spaceship must avoid colliding with the Rings
column3: or it will explode into a starburst of brilliant colors. The Spaceship dodges the Energy Rings by moving right or left across the playfield
column4: while bursting them with the Spaceship's 3-directional guns. Bursting the Large Rings (100 points) breaks them into Medium Rings. Bursting the Medium Rings (200 points) breaks them into Small Rings. Bursting the Small Rings (400 points) causes them to disintegrate.[-LF-]The Spaceship is further protected by a feature called a 'Warp' button. By depressing this button
column5: the Spaceship will relocate from the top or bottom of the screen to the opposite side.[-LF-]If the Spaceship is in ultimate danger of being destroyed
column6: releasing its Super Bomb will wipe out all the objects on the playfield
column7: and add the point value of the objects to your score. Use of the Super Bomb is lost
column8: if the ship is destroyed first. Only one Super Bomb is awarded per Spaceship.[-LF-]At any time
column9: a colorful Space Bogey resembling a Worm may appear on screen and proceed to chase the Spaceship. If the Worm is destroyed by Spaceship fire
column10: or dodged successfully for several seconds
column11: a 'clang' is heard and the Worm (500 points) wriggles off the screen in a bright red hue of embarrassment. If the Spaceship is caught by the Worm
column12: a bell is sounded
column13: and the astronaut is chased out of his ship in pursuit of safety.[-LF-]At random time intervals a Bonus Bug will walk across the playfield
column14: stop
column15: and count down a Bonus Number. This number is equal to 100 times its value. To receive this Bonus
column16: the Spaceship must link with the nose of the Bonus Bug.[-LF-]When the Spaceship has survived 50 Seconds of playing time
column17: it now enters the challenges of the next sector.[-LF-]The remaining 15 sectors are played in the same manner as Sector one. The differences include that each succeeding sector increases in difficulty. The Energy Rings increase in number and move faster across the screen making them harder to dodge. Also there are several Space Bogeys introduced in the first 8 sectors. They also increase in number with advancement through each sector. Some of the Space Bogeys resemble Comets whizzing through space. Others resemble Spaceships from other worlds. Each Space Bogey (500 points)
column18: is an assemblage of bright colors
column19: and when destroyed
column20: burst with a ""clang"" into a spray of bright light.[-LF-]Sectors 4
column23: and 16
column24: are alike as follows. A few seconds after the Energy Rings are broken into smaller pieces
column25: they are pulled into a Black Hole in the center of the screen. While swirling across the game area
column26: the condensed Rings expand and shatter into fragments which must be destroyed before they absorb the Spaceship.[-LF-]When Sector 16 has been accomplished
column27: it will return to Sector 9.[-LF-]When Bonus levels are achieved
column28: an additional Ship will be added to your game.[-LF-]CHALLENGER INSTRUCTIONS[-LF-]1. Burst energy rings to score and increase bonus levels.[-LF-]Large rings - 100 points[-LF-]Medium rings - 200 points[-LF-]Small rings - 400 points[-LF-]2. After all the small rings are hit
column29: advance to the next sector.[-LF-]3. In each sector
column30: space bogeys appear and score 500 points when hit.[-LF-]4. When the bonus bug walks across the playfield and stops
column31: bonus points are counted down. To collect the bonus
column32: link the ship with nose of the bug.[-LF-]5. Pressing the warp button immediately relocates the ship from the top or bottom of the playfield to the opposite side.[-LF-]6. A giant bomb ticks down the game seconds while devices of Dr. Boom's plotting
column6: such as bomb converters

column8: robot guards
column9: acid pits
column10: and crawling eyes shooting death rays
column11: challenge the player(s).[-LF-]CLOAK & DAGGER is a 1- or 2-player game with a color raster video display. You control Agent X as he descends underground floor by floor in an elevator to Dr. Boom's lab
column12: located on the 33rd floor. Your main goal is to retrieve Top Secret plans that are surrounded by an electrical arc. To stop the electrical current
column13: Agent X must shoot all the fiery nodes as he fights off robot guards.[-LF-]As Agent X leaves the elevator on each floor
column14: he must make his way carefully and quickly across the screen to another exit. Each floor displays a configuration of conveyor belts moving green unarmed and red armed explosives.  Agent X can pick up the green explosives. The red explosives will explode on contact. Some floors have marauding robot guards
column15: death-ray shooting crawling eyes
column16: and acid pits.[-LF-]Once Agent X has the top secret plans in hand
column17: he must make his way back to the surface. If he exits on a floor that was bombed on the way down
column18: he will find a massive crater protected by node monsters and the previously mentioned attackers. If he exits on a floor that was not bombed
column19: a superguard will join the other attackers to challenge Agent X. On the final level
column20: rumors are that he will meet the notorious Dr. Boom himself.[-LF-]At the center of the display
column21: a double-coiled fuse to a giant bomb is ticking down the game seconds for each level. Agent X can light the fuse in a rush for bonus points
column22: but must be able to escape that level before the bomb explodes. If the fuse has shortened on its own to one coil
column23: it lights automatically and prompts Agent X to make a mad dash to the waiting elevator. The doors close just as a burst of light from the explosion is seen. The game's perspective now changes to a full view inside the elevator. Messages flash across the elevator to give helpful hints on the next level.[-LF-]Dr. Boom has placed explosive mines on every 4th floor. On each of the preceding 3 floors Agent X can pick up a secret map box that will show him part of the safe path across the minefield on the next 4th floor.[-LF-]Agent X's first goal is to travel successfully from one elevator to the other; his second goal is to pick up a secret box to get a map of the minefield on levels 4
column30: and 32; the third goal is to light the bomb fuse and escape before the explosion.[-LF-]As game play progresses
column31: Agent X may find an extra-life box and a mystery box that give bonus points
column35: an extra life. Extra bonus points are earned for picking up green unarmed explosives or for skipping floors.[-LF-]If Agent X succeeds in capturing the top secret plans
column36: he must fight his way back up to the top level. The appearance of box compressors
column38: and other enemies are more random on the way up than on the way down. If Agent X makes it back to the surface
column39: a free game will be awarded (depending on the settings of the option switches).[-LF-]The game ends when you use up your last life or successfully make it to the surface.>

column2: the column puzzle pieces can be moved left and right as they fall

column5: pressing a button will cause the order of the colored blocks in a column to shift by one position.[-LF-]The object of the game is to place columns at the bottom of the pit in such a way that lines of 3 or more like-colored blocks are created (either horizontally

column7: these blocks disappear

column1: ddragon2>Double Dragon II - The Revenge>Technos Japan>Technos Japan>1988>Beat-'Em-Up>AAMA - Yellow (Animated Violence Mild)>1-2 Players>3.3>"Following his defeat at the end of the original Double Dragon Willy

column5: leaving the brothers with the task to avenge her death.[-LF-]The sequel to Double Dragon is essentially an upgraded version of the original game
column6: but with with a two-way attacking system similar to one previously used in Technos Japan's 1986 arcade game ""Renegade"". Many of the attacks and combos from the original ""Double Dragon"" are retained
column7: as well as new techniques including the invincible Cyclone Kick.[-LF-]The stages and weapons are redesigned versions of items previously featured in the original game. There are a few new traps such as a bulldozer in the middle of Mission 3 and all of the transition sequences between stages are now done with the character entering the next level via a lift
column8: making it impossible to carry one weapon to the next area.[-LF-]Most of the enemy characters return from the original Double Dragon
column9: with some given facelifts
column10: but the stage bosses are all new. The enemies are as followed :[-LF-]* Williams - Has a wilder face and longer hair. He can now run towards the player and do cartwheels. He throws his knives in mid-air and sometimes carry a shovel which he throws towards the player.[-LF-]* Roper - Has a beard and eye-patch
column11: but otherwise is more or less identical to his original self. He carries shovels and can sometime pick up large objects.[-LF-]* Linda - She now has a mohawk and face paint. She can also jump off platforms and do the elbow smash against the player. In addition to the ball and chain
column12: she also carries grenades and knives.[-LF-]* Abobo - Now has a longer hair and a beard
column13: but otherwise is identical to his original self.[-LF-]* Oharra - A head swap of Abobo with flap-top and a clean face. He fights the same way.[-LF-]* Jeff - Same as his original self
column14: but now carries grenades.[-LF-]* Burnov - The boss of Mission 1. An obese wrestler whose face is concealed with a mask. He grabs the player and throws similar punches in the face. After dying
column15: he will stand up and yell
column16: disappearing in front of the player and leaving only his clothes. In later encounters
column17: he will revive himself at least once.[-LF-]* Abore - The boss of Mission 2. A huge suspender-wearing strongman with Terminator-like sunglasses. His slaps and shoulder tackles do massive damage to the player.[-LF-]* Chin Taimei - The boss of Mission 3. A Chinese martial artists armed with twin kali sticks. In addition to his energy-drainin stick combo
column18: he also has a jump kick and sweep kick.[-LF-]* Willy - The boss of Mission 4. Looks like he does in the original game
column19: but now dresses in red. He still uses the same machine gun from the first game.[-LF-]* The clone - After defeating Willy
column20: the player will have to fight their character's evil self. This clone has all the techniques the player has
column21: but can also throw energy beams and possess the player's body to drain his energy.

ddragon3>Double Dragon 3 - The Rosetta Stone>Technos Japan>Technos Japan>1990>Beat-'Em-Up>AAMA - Yellow (Animated Violence Mild)>1-2 Players>1.9>A mysterious fortune teller warns Billy & Jimmy Lee about the rise of a powerful enemy in Egypt. Since the Lee brothers are looking for a true challenge to put their martial arts skills to the ultimate test they agree to face this mysterious new enemy. They embark on a world quest - joining up with new allies in the process - and try to lay claim to the famous 'Rossetta Stone'.[-LF-]The 3rd and final arcade entry of the Double Dragon series (not counting the later Neo-Geo fighting game based on the movie) features a completely gameplay system and graphics from the first two installments. The game can played by up to 2 or 3 players, depending on the cabinet and settings. The 3rd player takes control of a yellow-clad Lee brother named Sonny, who is exclusive to this game. Techniques from the previous games such as the hair grab and the elbow punch are gone, but new ones are added such as the belly-to-back throw and the back-to-back hurricane kick, as well as the ability to dash by tapping the joystick left or right twice.[-LF-]The game features weapon shops that allows the player to purchase power-ups by inserting additional tokens. The power-ups differ between stages differ between stages and are available as followed.[-LF-]* Extra Guys - Allows the player to control a new character who replaces the current fighter when he dies. There are three character types in addition to the Lee brothers.[-LF-]- The Urquidez Brothers (Roney, Sunny, Jonny) -  Tall European grapplers. They have the most energy of the four character types.  Up to three fighters can be have in reserve.[-LF-]- The Chin Brothers (Seimei, Taimei, Sinmei) - Chubby Chinese men with powerful attacks.[-LF-]- The Oyama Brothers (Masao, Kunio, Akira) - Japanese karate masters dressed in gis specializing in speedy attacks.[-LF-]* Tricks - The hurricane kick and the one-armed stand head butt are added to the player's move set. If the player's current character dies, then the new techniques will be inherited by the next character in reserve, if there is one.[-LF-]* Weapons - A nunchaku or sword are given player. Only the Lees can have purchase and wield weapons.[-LF-]* Energy - Restores the current character's life to 150%.[-LF-]* Power-Up - Increases the character's agility.[-LF-]There are 5 stages in the game :[-LF-]Mission 1 - America - The enemies in this stage are typical thugs and bikers. The first area takes place in a downtown area of city. After defeating the first wave of enemies, the player will enter a warehouse, where they encounter bikers that will try to run over them with their bike. The boss in this is Jim, a red-haired biker wearing a leather jacket.[-LF-]Mission 2 - China - The enemies are martial artists that specialize in flying kicks. The stage takes place in a single level set in a countryside near the Great Wall of China. The boss at the end of level is Li Cheng-Long, a Shaolin Martial Arts expert who resembles Bruce Lee. When he's down in life, he will wield out his club.[-LF-]Mission 3 - Japan - The enemies are samurai swordsmen. The first area takes place outside a castle, with bamboo traps and enemies coming out of walls. The second area takes place inside a castle, where the player will face a few more swordsmen before taking out on the boss, Ranzou, a ninja. He attacks with throwing stars and smoke bombs and splits into three forms when he's down on his life.[-LF-]Mission 4 - Italy - Consists of a single level set in the ruins of a coliseum. The enemies are roman archers. After defeating most of the archers, the boss Giuliano, a man decked in gladiator armor, will attempt to run the player over with his horse. After defeating all the archers, Giuliano will dismount at the end of the level and fight the player. He wields a long hand spear and can block attacks with his shield.[-LF-]Mission 5 - Egypt - The final stage is composed of seven levels, which includes a desert field, an underground forest, a trap room with stone pillars and giant hands emerging from the floor, a hall with a flying disc. Enemies include living tree men and rock creatures.,>

column1: defender>Defender>Williams>Williams>1980>Shoot-'Em-Up>AAMA - Green (Suitable For All Ages)>1 Player>3.5>Defender is an arcade video game developed released by Williams Electronics in 1980. A shooting game featuring two-dimensional (2D) graphics

dkong>Donkey Kong>Nintendo of America>Nintendo of America>1981>Platform>AAMA - Green (Suitable For All Ages)>1-2 Players>4.0>Donkey Kong is an arcade game released by Nintendo in 1981. It is an early example of the platform game genre
column2: as the gameplay focuses on maneuvering the main character across a series of platforms while dodging and jumping over obstacles. In the game
column3: Jumpman (since renamed Mario) must rescue a damsel in distress
column4: Lady (now named Pauline) from a giant ape named Donkey Kong. The hero and ape later became two of Nintendo's most popular characters.The game was the latest in a series of efforts by Nintendo to break into the North American market. Hiroshi Yamauchi
column5: Nintendo's president at the time
column6: assigned the project to a first-time game designer named Shigeru Miyamoto. Drawing from a wide range of inspirations
column7: including Popeye
column8: Beauty and the Beast and King Kong
column9: Miyamoto developed the scenario and designed the game alongside Nintendo's chief engineer
column10: Gunpei Yokoi. The two men broke new ground by using graphics as a means of characterization
column11: including cut scenes to advance the game's plot
column12: and integrating multiple stages into the gameplay.Despite initial misgivings on the part of Nintendo's American staff
column13: Donkey Kong proved a success in North America and Japan. Nintendo licensed the game to Coleco
column14: who developed home console versions for numerous platforms. Other companies cloned Nintendo's hit and avoided royalties altogether. Miyamoto's characters appeared on cereal boxes
column15: television cartoons
column16: and dozens of other places. A lawsuit brought on by Universal City Studios
column17: alleging Donkey Kong violated their trademark of King Kong
column18: ultimately failed. The success of Donkey Kong and Nintendo's win in the courtroom helped position the company to dominate the video game market from its release in 1981
column19: until the mid 1990s.>

column1: docastle>Mr. Do's Castle>Universal>Universal>1983>Platform>AAMA - Green (Suitable For All Ages)>1-2 Players>4.6>"For the second game in the Mr. Do. series the clown finds himself in a traditional platforms and ladders game. Each level is made up of six floors (seven including the castle's ramparts) and all are joined by a number of inter-connecting ladders. The ladders come in two different varieties: vertical ladders
column2: which are fixed and cannot be moved; and diagonal ladders
column3: which can be pushed left or right from the top of the ladder. This allows Mr. Do. to reach other areas of the level and is sometimes necessary to redirect the path of any pursuing enemies.[-LF-]The enemies in ""Mr Do's Castle"" come in the form of unicorns
column4: and as with the enemies of the first game
column5: they will hunt down and try to kill Mr. Do. Replacing the 'Powerball' weapon of the original game
column6: Mr Do is now armed with a mallet. This can be used to temporarily stun the game's unicorns and buy the player time to escape; but its primary function is to knock out the floor blocks that form each level's platforms.[-LF-]Most blocks are marked with a cherry and collecting all of these will complete the level. A level can also be completed by killing all of the unicorns. This is achieved by using the mallet to remove blocks and knock holes in the platforms. The unicorns will fall into any holes that the player has created; some simply fall through to the platform below
column7: whereas others are trapped. Trapped unicorns can be hit with Mr. Do's mallet and knocked to a lower platform - useful for buying a few extra seconds for the player. If left alone
column8: however
column9: the unicorns will climb out
column10: filling the hole in behind them
column11: and transform into much nastier enemies. These new enemies cannot be stunned with the mallet and must be killed by dropping blocks onto them from the platform above.[-LF-]Some sections of a platform have two 'skull' blocks at either end of them
column12: with normal cherry blocks in-between. When both skull blocks are knocked out with the mallet
column13: all the blocks in between will fall to reveal wooden floorboards. This is highly effective in killing several enemies at once.[-LF-]Each level also has three 'Key' blocks. If Mr.Do. knocks out all of the key blocks
column14: a large door opens at the top of the screen to reveal a shield which
column15: when collected
column16: turns the unicorns into 'Alphamonsters'. The Alphamonsters flee from Mr. Do. and can be killed either with the mallet
column17: or by dropping a floor block onto them from above. When Mr. Do. kills an Alphamonster

domino>Domino Man>Bally Midway>Bally Midway>1982>Puzzle>AAMA - Green (Suitable For All Ages)>1-2 Players>2.4>The player controls Domino Man, a bespectacled, moustachioed artist who must set up a chain of giant dominoes across the screen, to form a chain of dominoes which can then be toppled.[-LF-]The dominoes must be placed on sites marked by black spots, achieved by simply running over each spot. Once all of the spots are covered with a domino, the chain is complete. The player will then have the choice of either knocking them all down to clear the level, or simply wait for a few seconds to continue to the next screen, in hope of completing the chain on THAT level, and so on. In this way, the player can set up several chains and knock them all down in one fell swoop, earning many bonus points in the process. Multiple chains are, of course, very difficult to achieve.[-LF-]Domino Man's progress is hampered by a neighborhood bully who walks onto the screen and tries to knock over the first dominoes he comes across. The player must either try to complete and topple the chain of dominoes before the bully knocks them over, or hit the bully with a domino; causing the bully's trousers to fall down and disabling him for a few seconds. A killer bee also appears, and if it manages to sting the player, a life is lost. A bag lady and a boy pushing a shopping cart wander blindly around the levels, occasioanlly knocking over some of the dominoes. Domio Man can hit them, however, causing them to change direction.[-LF-]Once a game is over, a poem is displayed on-screen to evaluate the player's performance on the game. For example :[-LF-]Roses are red[-LF-]Or so goes the verse,[-LF-]You set up fifty-two[-LF-]You could have done worse.>

donpachi>DonPachi>Cave>Atlus>1995>Shoot-'Em-Up>AAMA - Green (Suitable For All Ages)>1-2 Players>4.8>DonPachi (首領蜂?) est un jeu vidéo développé par Cave. Il s’agit d’un shoot them up à défilement vertical de type manic shooter. Il est publié en 1995 sur borne d'arcade, puis porté sur Saturn et PlayStation en 1996. C'est le tout premier jeu de la société Cave. Il connaît une suite en 1996, DoDonPachi.Le joueur incarne un pilote dont la mission est de survivre à un exercice grandeur nature d'une durée de huit ans. Les pilotes participant à cette épreuve ont pour but de prouver leur valeur afin de se montrer digne d'entrer dans le futur escadron d'élite DonPachi. L'exercice est toutefois rendu difficile aussi bien physiquement que psychologiquement car les ennemis du pilote sont ses propres camarades, se sacrifiant pour permettre aux pilotes les plus doués de survivre et réussir l'épreuve.>

esckids>Escape Kids>Konami>Konami>1991>Sports/Track & Field>AAMA - Green (Suitable For All Ages)>1-4 Players>3.9>I guess that explains why so many of today's games are drab, brown affairs - Konami used up all the coloured pixels in the nineties. espgal2>Espgaluda II>Cave>AMI>2005>Shoot-'Em-Up>AAMA - Green (Suitable For All Ages)>1-2 Players>4.1>Espgaluda II (エスプガルーダII) is a manic shooter originally released by Cave in the arcades in 2005 as a sequel to Espgaluda.The game takes place in a fictional land called Soma, three years after a massive war known as the Great Shinra War devastated the land and killed most of its plant life. Humanity is forced to pull their efforts together for the sake of survival and reforestation. Using new found technology, an alchemist named Hiodoshi spearheaded a project called Project Espgaluda, which gathered youths and used them as experimental test subjects for artificial armored wings. They were then called Galuda, named after the mythical bird of legend.Ageha and Tateha were two of the subjects who escaped during the project. At the end of Espgaluda, they were reunited with their mother and lived peacefully after going into hiding. Espgaluda II begins when they are discovered.>

column3: and is a direct successor to Namco's two earlier Pole Position games (1982-1983).Final Lap was the first racing game to allow up to eight players to simultaneously race on the Suzuka Circuit
column4: in a Formula One race. This was
column5: at the time
column6: considered a revolutionary feature and was implemented by linking together up to four two-player sitdown-style arcade cabinets.[2][3] It was also arguably the first racing game to implement ""rubber banding"" to ensure that less talented players were never too far behind the leader

column2: released in 1979. The gameplay of Galaga puts the player in control of a space ship which is situated on the bottom of the screen. At the beginning of each stage
column3: the area is empty
column4: but over time
column5: enemy aliens fly in formation
column6: and once all of the enemies arrive on screen
column7: they will come down at the player's ship in formations of one or more and may either shoot it or collide with it. During the entire stage
column8: the player may fire upon the enemies
column9: and once all enemies are vanquished
column10: the player moves onto the next stage.Galaga has proven very successful. The arcade version of it has been ported to many consoles
column11: and it has had several sequels
column12: most recently Galaga Legions for the Xbox Live Arcade service.The objective of Galaga is to score as many points as possible by destroying insect-like enemies. The player controls a starfighter that can move left and right along the bottom of the playfield. Enemies swarm in groups in a formation near the top of the screen
column13: and then begin flying down toward the player
column14: firing bombs at the fighter. The game ends when the player's last fighter is lost
column15: either by colliding with an enemy or one of its bullets
column16: or by being captured.Galaga introduces a number of new features over its predecessor
column17: Galaxian. Among these is the ability to fire more than one bullet at a time
column18: a count of the player's ""hit/miss ratio"" at the end of the game
column19: and a bonus ""Challenging Stage"" that occurs every few levels
column20: in which a series of enemies fly onto and out of the screen in set patterns without firing at the player's ship or trying to crash into it.">

column1: galaga88>Galaga '88>Namco>Namco>1987>Shoot-'Em-Up>AAMA - Green (Suitable For All Ages)>1-2 Players>4.4>"The gameplay in Galaga '88 is built on the same premise as that of the original Galaga game
column2: but is in many ways more complex and more difficult. The game is divided into a series of 29 Stages distributed through eight Worlds. The starship Galaga accelerates between Stages and Worlds and even to higher dimensions (go to the section on Dimensional Travel below to find out more).With the exception of the third and eighth
column3: each World culminates in a Challenging Stage. There are six such stages to engage in any full game
column4: and each begins with the on-screen announcement ""That's Galactic Dancin'!"" and has its own YM2151-generated song to which the enemy formations dance. In any given Challenging Stage
column5: both the design of the enemies and their dancing formations shall vary according to the player's current Dimension. As in Galaga
column6: the objective is to destroy all forty enemies before they fly away off the screen. However
column7: refraining completely from touching any controls for the duration of a Challenging Stage awards a ""secret bonus"" ranging in value from 10000 to 25000 points
column8: and equal to the ""special bonus"" which would have been awarded for destroying all forty enemy aliens instead.Galaga '88 introduces a variety of new enemies and behaviors. Most of these special enemies are worth varying amounts of bonus points when destroyed. Some enemies can combine into larger enemies which take multiple hits to destroy
column9: while others arrive in eggs
column10: explode in a shower of fireworks
column11: grow with multiple hits
column12: or sport armor which makes them invincible while in formation. Certain enemies drop small formations of tiny creatures that wiggle their way down the screen
column13: and still others can act as escorts to incoming groups of enemies and then quickly dive at the player before leaving the game. Most stages also include various obstacles which appear once the enemy formation has been assembled. These can be destroyed with either one or several shots
column14: and the first one on each stage will leave a ""Warp Capsule"".At the start of the game
column15: the player can select how many Galaga starships to start with (one or two)
column16: affecting their number of remaining lives. The game ends after the final boss is defeated (or when the player's last ship is destroyed or captured) - in the latter case
column17: the player can continue the game for an additional credit. The Game Over screen shows the player's hit-miss ratio and a visual representation of their progress. If the player reaches Stage 27
column18: the game also shows a picture of the final boss (damaged if defeated
column19: but silhouetted if not). If the arcade operator has set the ""continue"" option to ""on""
column20: the player also cannot continue if he is defeated on Stages 27-29.">

column1: gaplus>Gaplus>Namco>Namco>1984>Shoot-'Em-Up>AAMA - Green (Suitable For All Ages)>1-2 Players>4.3>"The 3rd game in Namco's classic ""Galaxian"" series Gaplus picks up where 1981's ""Galaga"" left off. While maintaining the same classic 'look' of its predecessor
column2: Gaplus's graphics a definite improvement over those of Galaga; the game's increased colour palette and subtle use of shading making the attacking aliens look rather more solid.[-LF-]Another enhancement over its prequel is in the addition of a player-acquired 'Tractor Beam'. In Galaga

column5: the player can now acquire the Tractor Beam. This is achieved by shooting one of the alien formation's 'generals' - a visibly more colourful alien than its comrades. The Tractor Beam will then activate for a limited time and any aliens the players captures (up to a maximum of six) will dock alongside the player's ship for enhanced firepower.[-LF-]One final yet important addition is in the movement of the player's ship. gravitar>Gravitar>Atari>Atari>1982>Shoot-'Em-Up>AAMA - Green (Suitable For All Ages)>1 Player>3.5>The player controls a small blue spacecraft. The game starts in a fictional solar system with several planets to explore. If the player moves his ship into a planet, he will be taken to a side-view landscape. Unlike many other shooting games, gravity plays a fair part in Gravitar: the ship will be pulled slowly to the deadly star in the overworld, and downward in the side-view levels.The player has five buttons: two to rotate the ship left or right, one to shoot, one to activate the thruster, and one for both a tractor beam and force field. Gravitar, Asteroids, Asteroids Deluxe and Space Duel all used similar 5-button controlling system.In the side-view levels, the player has to destroy red bunkers that shoot constantly, and can also use the tractor beam to pick up blue fuel tanks. Once all of the bunkers are destroyed, the planet will blow up, and the player will earn a bonus. Once all planets are destroyed, the player will move onto another solar system.The player will lose a life if he crashes into the terrain or gets hit by an enemy's shot, and the game will end immediately if fuel runs out.Gravitar has 12 different planets. Red Planet is available in all 3 phases in the universe; it contains a reactor. Shooting the reactor core activates a link. Escaping the reactor successfully moves the player to the next phase of planets, awards bonus points and 7500 units of fuel. Reactor escape time reduces after each phase and eventually becomes virtually impossible to complete.After completing all 11 planets (or alternatively completing the reactor three times) the player enters the second universe and the gravity will reverse. Instead of dragging the ship towards the planet surface, the gravity pushes it away. In the third universe the landscape becomes invisible and the gravity is positive again. The final, fourth universe, has invisible landscape and reverse gravity. After completing the fourth universe the game starts over. However, the reactor escape time will never reset back to high levels again.The programmers thought that even the best players could never complete the most difficult planets on the invisible levels.>

gunfight>Gun Fight>Dave Nutting Associates>Midway>1975>Shooter>AAMA - Green (Suitable For All Ages)>1-2 Players>3.3>Each player (2 people play at a time--there is no computer opponent) controls a gunfighter. Your left hand has a 4-way joystick which moves your gunfighter anywhere on your side of the screen. Your right hand has a gun grip which tilts up and down to aim your gunfighter's pistol and which has a trigger to fire. Your only goal is to shoot the other player who is right across the screen from you; he will then fall down and say 'Got Me'. It isn't usually a straight shot
column2: as there will always be cactuses

column1: gyruss>Gyruss>Konami>Konami>1983>Shooter>AAMA - Green (Suitable For All Ages)>1-2 Players>2.0>"Gyruss (ジャイラス Jairasu?) is a shoot 'em up video arcade game developed by Konami

column4: and was ported to numerous games consoles and home computers. It follows in the tradition of space war games such as Space Invaders and Galaga.Gyruss was the second and last game Yoshiki Okamoto designed for Konami

column6: he was fired after the release of this game

column13: was achieved by utilizing discrete audio circuits. The game used three microprocessors: two Z80 microprocessors and one 6809
column14: as well as an 8039 microcontroller. For the sound
column15: five AY-3-8910 PSG sound chips and a DAC.Gyruss was released in both upright and cocktail cabinets.R.Hirst ""KOO""

harddriv>Hard Drivin'>Atari Games>Atari Games>1999>Driving>AAMA - Green (Suitable For All Ages)>1 Player>3.8>Slide into the contoured seat and adjust it to fit the length of your arms and legs. Put your feet on gas and clutch pedals and try the stick shift. Select manual or automatic transmission
column2: turn the ignition key and you're off![-LF-]It?s the ride of your life. You feel the tires grip the road when you take a wide turn at high speed. You're alerted to the smallest change in the road by the feedback steering. You catch air as you fly the draw bridge and land on the down ramp. You control the car as it holds the road on the dizzying vertical loop.[-LF-]Hard Drivin' might look like an arcade game but it drives like a real car. For the best lap times
column3: drive Hard Drivin' as if it were a real car. The main difference between Hard Drivin' and a real car is that Hard Drivin' is much safer to drive. A player can test the limits of our car and his skill with no risk of personal injury
column4: and follow a course that does not exist anywhere m the real world.[-LF-]After inserting the proper number of coins to start the simulator
column5: the player can select either an automatic or manual transmission. Turning the ignition key starts the simulator.[-LF-]Drivers can choose between the stunt track or the speed track by following the posted signs on the road. Each player has a certain (operator-selectable) amount of time to reach a checkpoint or the finish line. Crossing checkpoints and the finish line rewards the player with (operator-selectable) bonus driving time.[-LF-]With Hard Drivin' a player can test drive a high-powered sports car on a real stunt course. He can jump a draw bridge
column6: negotiate a high-speed banked turn and drive a 360-degree vertical loop. These thrilling stunts
column7: among others
column8: provide the ultimate realistic driving experience.[-LF-]Or maybe high-speed driving is a particular player's type of excitement. He can 'put the pedal to the metal' and try to keep control around the corners
column9: weaving in and out of traffic while avoiding oncoming cars. All this
column10: and more
column11: await the player behind the wheel of Hard Drivin'.[-LF-]Players especially enjoy the unique instant replay feature on Hard Drivin'.  Every time a player crashes
column12: the simulator records and replays the crash sequence. Not only will the player find this entertaining
column13: but it is also informative. The instant replay shows the player exactly what he did wrong and why he crashed (If a player wants to skip the instant replay
column14: he can press the abort switch or turn the key when the replay starts).[-LF-]A skilled player finds the ultimate competition in the 'challenge' lap (or 'grudge match' as Atari Games likes to call it). The simulator remembers the path of the car driven by the best driver on record.  When a player beats the qualifying lap time
column15: he challenges the car of the past winner in a head-to-head race.>

column5: having to investigate the sewers of New York after strange creatures have been appearing down there. The objective of the game is to defeat all of the enemies in each phase. The mechanics of Mario Bros. involve only running and jumping. Unlike future Mario games
column6: players cannot jump on enemies and squash them
column7: unless they were already turned on their back. Each phase is a series of platforms with four pipes at each corner of the screen (in the old version along with an object called a ""POW"" block in the center). Both sides of every phase feature a mechanism that allows the player to go off-screen to the left and appear on the right and vice versa.The player gains points by defeating multiple enemies consecutively and can participate in a bonus round to gain more points. Enemies are defeated by kicking them over once they have been flipped on their back. This is accomplished by hitting the platform the enemy is on directly beneath them. If the player allows too much time to pass after doing this
column8: the enemy will flip itself back over
column9: changing in color and increasing speed. Each phase has a certain number of enemies
column10: with the final enemy immediately changing color and increasing its speed to maximum. There are three enemies in all: the Shellcreeper
column11: which simply walks around; the Sidestepper
column12: which requires two hits to flip over; and the Fighter Fly
column13: which moves by jumping and can only be flipped when it is touching a platform. Players may also make use of the above-mentioned ""POW"" block
column14: which flips any enemy touching a platform or the floor when a player hits it from below. This item can be used three times before it disappears. Coins appear whenever enemies are defeated and may be collected for bonus points.As the game progresses
column15: elements are added to increase the difficulty. Fireballs either bounce around the screen or travel directly from one side to the other
column16: and Slipices can freeze platforms
column17: causing Mario and Luigi to skid. In addition
column18: icicles start to form under the platforms and fall loose. Bonus rounds give the players a chance to score extra points by collecting coins without having to deal with enemies; the ""POW"" block regenerates itself on each of these screens.">

megatack>Megatack>Game Plan>Centuri>1980>Shoot-'Em-Up>AAMA - Green (Suitable For All Ages)>1-2 Players>1.3>"SINGLE PLAYER GAME[-LF-]The game-play sequence in MEGATTACK consists of 4 or 5 turns (operator selectable) each of which lasts as long as the player can skillfully maneuver his spacepod to avoid destruction. When he loses a spacepod
column2: the GIP message reappears
column3: accompanied by the GIP sound
column4: and displays the number of spacepods left. After the last spacepod is destroyed
column5: the game-over sound is heard and the game-over message is displayed.[-LF-]Assuming a (4) pod game
column6: play begins with player-scores (00000) and at the top and the (3) best scores displayed across the bottom Eight (8) monsters appear in the upper portion of the screen and move towards the bottom
column7: while dropping their bombs. The player uses his joystick control to move his spacepod across the bottom of the screen. The spacepod will start with the number (4) in the center and the number will decrease each time a spacepod is destroyed so that the number (1) will be in the center on the last round.[-LF-]As the spacepod is moved across the bottom of the screen the player fires his laser energy-beams towards the left
column8: right
column9: and straight-up accompanied by an echoing laser sound effect. The laser beams have unlimited range
column10: covering the entire play-field
column11: and each spacepod has an unlimited number of shots. The (3) laser beams are fired simultaneously. Each fire-button must be released and pressed again to fire a second shot. Also
column12: there is a slight ""reload"" delay so that beams cannot-be fired too rapidly.[-LF-]Whenever a laser beam strikes a monster or a bomb
column13: it explodes with a visual flash and an audio blast. If a monster is blasted
column14: the player is awarded a 'kill' and his score is increased by the appropriate score (per the scoring menu when a bomb is blasted
column15: no points are scored.[-LF-]When a spacepod is hit by a bomb
column16: it explodes with a growing flash and a reverberating blast. When the spacepod gets too close to a monster
column17: the monster jumps up and sporadically devours it while growling and burping
column18: if a monster reaches the bottom
column19: it bounces across the bottom in an attempt to devour the spacepod.[-LF-]When all the monsters in a given round have been destroyed the screen will turn into a starfield
column20: and small space rings will appear
column21: which if not shot at
column22: hit
column23: and destroyed will grow in size. If any one (1) ring is allowed to reach a predetermined size
column24: it will de-activate the spacepods laser gun
column25: which during these rounds only fires straight up
column26: lift the spacepod off the bottom of the screen
column27: absorb it and then disappear (shrinking in size)
column28: thus ending the round. The next round begins with the next wave of monsters. This starfield round occurs between every wave of monsters
column29: and if the player is successful in destroying all the rings the next wave of monsters will then appear.[-LF-]When the spacepod is finally destroyed either by being absorbed
column30: hit by a bomb or devoured by a monster the round is over and the video image returns to the GIP display flashing player (1) up and displaying the remaining spacepods the screen then goes black again and this time the pod with the number (3) in the center appears at the bottom of the screen and play continues as before.[-LF-]During play there are always (8) monsters (max) on the screen
column31: however the monsters attack in waves of 25
column32: after each multiple of 25 kills the starfield or space ring round will appear with each ring worth the same score as the monsters were worth in the previous screen display. The monsters that reappear after each space ring round are a new shape
column33: and color and score more points
column34: and drop a different color bomb
column35: any monsters left at the end of a round will reappear at the beginning of the next round. At the beginning of the game the action is rather moderate to allow new players an opportunity to develop a 'feel' for the game. In each succeeding wave of monsters
column36: the bombs begin to fall at an increased rate and the monsters motions are increased.[-LF-]All of these features combine to make MEGATTACK satisfying for the novice
column38: and profitable for the operator.[-LF-]TWO-PLAYER MODE[-LF-]The play of MEGATTACK in a two-player game is identical to single-play with the players alternating turns. On the Upright Version
column39: the players use one common set of controls. On the cocktail version there are two sets of controls on opposite sides of the table. The computer activates control alternately between player 1 and 2 and flip-flops the screen image so that it is oriented to the player in control.[-LF-]The GIP message
column41: clearly indicates which player is up by flashing it in the player's color. This also allows time for the players to position themselves at the controls
column42: but is brief enough to avoid unnecessary ""dead-time"". The use of two different player-colors eliminates any confusion as to which player is in control.">

It is considered one of the most notable games from the Golden Age of Video Arcade Games. The plot of Missile Command is simple: the player's six cities are being attacked by an endless hail of ballistic missiles, some of them even splitting like multiple independently targetable reentry vehicles (MIRVs), and in later levels smart bombs which can evade a less than perfectly targeted missile. As a regional commander of three anti-missile batteries, the player must defend six cities in their zone from being destroyed.>

mrdo>Mr. Do!>Universal>Universal>1982>Maze>AAMA - Green (Suitable For All Ages)>1-2 Players>4.7>Mr. Do! is a colourful and addictive maze game in which the player takes on the role of the eponymous Mr. Do a circus clown who must clear each level of either cherries or monsters. The game's single screen levels are made up of tunnels surrounded by a colourful
column2: soil-like substance. This soil can be dug through to create new tunnels
column3: allowing Mr. Do to escape his enemies and to reach the many cherries that litter the levels. A number of apples are also scattered around each level
column4: and Mr. Do can push them along tunnels (to block and/or kill monsters) or can tunnel beneath them to drop them onto the heads of any pursuing enemies. Mr. Do himself can also be killed by a falling apple.[-LF-]Mr. Do is armed with a 'Powerball' that can be fired down a tunnel
column5: it will then bounce around the tunnels until it either returns to Mr. Do
column6: or comes into contact with
column7: and kills
column8: one of the level's monsters. The Powerball will only return once Mr. Do has tunneled under more soil. As each level progresses
column9: the monsters themselves start to dig tunnels of their own in their pursuit of Mr. Do. Monsters can also push the apples.[-LF-]Each screen has a doorway through which the monsters enter the level. Once all of the monsters have appeared

column11: (ice cream
column12: biscuits
column13: etc.). If the player collects the prize

The Alphamonster and his henchmen cannot be easily crushed under apples because they tend to eat them. They can be killed individually with the Powerball or by killing the Alphamonster itself
column15: at which point any remaining henchmen will turn into apples.[-LF-]After every three levels
column16: there is a brief intermission in which a tune is played and a large
column17: animated Mr. Do appears
column18: together with some of the game's monsters. The time to complete each level and the preferred method (monsters
column19: cherries
column20: EXTRA or Diamond) is shown. The paths in the first level resemble a 'D'
column21: after this each level's tunnels resemble a digit
column24: '4' etc.) up to '0' for level 10.[-LF-]A level can be completed any one of several different ways : either by collecting all of the on-screen cherries; by killing all of the monsters
column25: by completing the EXTRA box
column26: or by collecting the diamond. The latter appears only very occasionally ('Special' awards an extra credit).

mspacman>Ms. Pac-Man>Midway>General Computer Corporation>1981>Maze>AAMA - Green (Suitable For All Ages)>1-2 Players>4.4>In this the first proper sequel to Namco's legendary pill eating maze game
column6: players must once again run around a number of mazes
column7: eating all of the pills that are scattered throughout. The ever-present ghosts (Blinky
column8: Pinky
column9: Inky and Sue) return to hamper the player's progress. The infamous 'Power Pills' are also present and correct
column10: with four appearing in each maze.[-LF-]Namco introduced a number of changes and enhancements over the original game. The first difference is in the main character. For the first time in video-game history
column11: the game's lead character was female. Ms. Pac-Man is almost identical to the original character with two main differences; she wears a bow in her 'hair'
column12: and is also wearing lipstick.[-LF-]Another change from the original is that the bonus fruit items are no longer static but now move randomly around the mazes.[-LF-]Ms Pac-Man features 4 different maze layouts
column13: which alternate every 2 to 4 screens :[-LF-]The 1st maze is only encountered in Rounds 1 and 2
column14: and has 220 dots and 4 Power Pills. There are 2 sets of tunnels in this maze equidistant from the center of the maze. You must clear this maze 2 times before moving on to the next maze.[-LF-]The 2nd maze is only encountered in Rounds 3
column16: and 5
column17: and has 240 dots and 4 Power Pills. There are 2 sets of tunnels in this maze; one set in the lower half
column18: and the other set at the very top. You must clear this maze 3 times before moving on to the next maze.[-LF-]The 3rd maze is first encountered in Round 6 and has 238 dots and 4 Power Pills. Unlike all other mazes
column19: there is only 1 set of tunnels in this maze
column20: slightly above the center of the board. You must clear this maze 4 times before moving on to the next maze.[-LF-]The 4rth and final unique maze is first encountered in Round 10 and has 234 dots and 4 Power Pills. There are 2 sets of tunnels in this maze
column21: directly next to one another in the middle of the maze. The turns at the entrance to the tunnels change the usual immediate accessibility of the tunnels and should be taken in to account. You must clear this maze 4 times before moving on to the next maze.[-LF-]After Round 13
column22: the game alternates every 4 rounds between the third and fourth mazes.[-LF-]Finally
column23: the ghosts' movement patterns are also completely different to those of the original game.[-LF-]As in the original game
column24: intermission scenes will be played after certain rounds. Ms. Pac-Man's intermissions tell the story of how Pac-Man and Ms. Pac-Man met

column27: the star of the original game

msword>Magic Sword: Heroic Fantasy>Capcom>Capcom>1990>Beat-'Em-Up>AAMA - Yellow (Animated Violence Mild)>1-2 Players>2.8>Magic Sword fully titled as Magic Sword: Heroic Fantasy, is a side-scrolling fantasy arcade game released by Capcom in 1990. The game casts the player as a hero who must fight his way through a mystical tower in order to save the world. The player can use a sword, axe or magic, and can also rescue and recruit potential allies of various character classes, each of which has his or her own special abilities. Three years earlier, Capcom had released the similar Black Tiger in 1987.>
mtlchamp>Martial Champion>Konami>Konami>1993>Fighter>AAMA - Yellow (Animated Violence Mild)>1-4 Players>2.6>Martial Champion is a versus fighting game similar in concept to Street Fighter II. There are ten characters to choose from, each representing his or her own country. The main protagonist is a Japanese martial artist named Jin; others include his countryman Zen, a kabuki fighter; a Chinese kung-fu expert and a vampire from Hong-Kong; an Egyptian princess; a scimitar fighter from Saudi Arabia; a spear-wielding Kenyan warrior; a French weapons specialist; and two North Americans - an eyepatched soldier and a blonde female ninja-like fighter.>

pbobble3>Puzzle Bobble 3>Taito Corporation>Taito Corporation>1996>Puzzle>AAMA - Green (Suitable For All Ages)>1-2 Players>4.6>Puzzle Bobble 3 (also known as Bust-A-Move 3) is the second sequel to Puzzle Bobble. It would be the final appearance of Puzzle Bobble on the Sega Saturn. Like its predecessors, the player is tasked with shooting balls at groups of balls, creating groups of 3 or more, which are then removed from play. A European remake is entitled Bust-a-Move 3 DX. released in America as Bust-a-Move '99.>

The aim is to forms chains of like-colored bubbles

column4: making life more difficult for the players. The game is over when the bubbles reach the very bottom of the play area.[-LF-]In the 1-player game there are thirty rounds to complete

column6: the winner is the player who clears their play area first. The addictive yet straightforward game-play mechanic ensured that the ""Puzzle Bobble"" games would be the most successful of their genre since Russian programmer

phoenix>Phoenix (Amstar)>Amstar>Amstar>1980>Shoot-'Em-Up>AAMA - Green (Suitable For All Ages)>1-2 Players>4.4>Phoenix is a classic shoot-em-up in the mould of Taito's ""Space Invaders"" and Namco's ""Galaxian"" but takes the concept further with the introduction of progressive stages of play (instead of simply repeating a single playfield over and over with an increasing difficulty level).[-LF-]The player's ship moves along the botton of the playfield firing upwards. The ship can also utilize a temporary 'Force Field' to protect it from missiles and birds. Any Phoenix that collide with the Force Field are destroyed. The Force Field only lasts for two seconds and then cannot be used again for another five seconds.[-LF-]There are five attack waves to each round of play.[-LF-]The first wave begins with a formation of sixteen Phoenix attacking the player's ship. They drop missiles and dive at the ship in an effort to destroy it.[-LF-]The second wave is a variation of the first
column9: only with a different enemy attack pattern.[-LF-]The third wave begins with pattern of eight eggs that when shot hatch into blue Phoenix birds that then attack the player's ship. These birds can be destroyed by rocket fire from the ship. If the rocket hits the bird on center
column10: the bird is destroyed. If the rocket hits the bird to the left or right of center
column11: only that wing of the bird is destroyed. The wing will regenerate itself if the bird is not quickly destroyed.[-LF-]The fourth wave is similar to the third
column12: only with two banks of eggs instead of one.[-LF-]The fifth and final wave is the attack of the Space fortress mothership; a huge mothership piloted by a purple-coloured alien that sends down waves of small birds to attack the player's ship
column13: as well as launching missiles from the fortress itself. The alien is protected by a barrier that must be shot several times before both the alien and mothership are destroyed.[-LF-]Once the mothership has been destroyed

column2: this game is sure to challenge the most avid player.[-LF-]Each round of play includes 4 different stages. With the onset of the melodious background tune
column3: the first stage of play begins.[-LF-]Against a backdrop of planets and twinkling stars
column4: the Earth City must be protected from sixteen attacking Martians. These Martian attackers have the ability to transform from flying Martians
column5: to walking Martians
column6: or to UFOs. The walking Martians build barriers across the Earth City. These barriers must be destroyed.[-LF-]The Earth Spaceship can be maneuvered right and left. With the use of the 'warp' button
column7: it can be randomly relocated when necessary. These
column8: plus a backup of stationary defense weapons
column9: aid in protecting the Earth City and Spaceship
column10: as well as in destroying the Martian Attackers. When all but the two final Martians have been destroyed
column11: a tone of dusk shades the Earth City. As these two attackers meet their end
column12: the Earth Spaceship ascends into space to meet the challenge of Stage II.[-LF-]In this second stage of play
column13: the Earth Spaceship encounters eight Space Monsters. To destroy these Monsters
column14: they must be hit in the direct center. When a Space Monster with burning wings is destroyed
column15: up to 400 points can be added to your score. When all the Space Monsters have been destroyed
column16: the Earth Spaceship prepares for Stage III.[-LF-]In this third stage of play
column17: the Earth Spaceship is confronted with the Martian Space Battleship and its unseen forces. This Martian Battleship contains five closed chambers
column18: each protected by a rocket flame. Each chamber opens periodically at random
column19: to release a defending reserve of Martian attackers. When a flame below an open chamber is extinguished
column20: point value of the Martian Space Battleship increases. This enemy ship can be destroyed by either eliminating all sixteen Martian attackers
column21: or by extinguishing all five rocket flames. When the Martian Space Battleship finally explodes
column22: the Earth Spaceship moves on to Stage IV.[-LF-]This last stage of play begins with an emergency signal
column23: SOS
column24: SOS
column25: SOS
column26: AT ONCE RETURN TO EARTH. The Earth Spaceship is now ready to be guided on its journey
column27: through a landing corridor
column28: back to its home base. The Earth Spaceship must be carefully maneuvered around other spaceships in order to avoid destruction. Clearing flags will add bonus points to your score. When the Earth Spaceship has been safely maneuvered to its arrival target
column30: 000 points will be added to your score
column31: while bursts of fireworks greet your arrival and signal the beginning of a new round of play.

column1: polepos>Pole Position>Namco>Namco>1982>Driving>AAMA - Green (Suitable For All Ages)>1 Player>4.4>"Pole Position is a racing video game released in 1982 by Namco. It was published by Namco in Japan and by Atari
column2: Inc. in the United States. The game popularized the use of sprite-based
column3: pseudo-3D graphics with its ""rear-view racer format""—where the player’s view is behind and above the vehicle

column1: polepos2>Pole Position II (Japan)>Namco>Namco>1983>Driving>AAMA - Green (Suitable For All Ages)>1 Player>4.2>Pole Position II is a 1-player game using a color raster-scan video display. Game action takes place at 4 different raceways - the Fuji Speedway in Japan the Test Track (an oval track like Indy)
column2: the Seaside Speedway (with the Long Beach Pike in the background)
column3: and the Suzuka Speedway in Japan. The unique and picturesque scenery around each raceway adds exciting realism to each race![-LF-]The driver drives a Formula-1 race car on each track. Player controls consist of a steering wheel
column4: a two-position gear shifter
column5: an accelerator
column6: and a brake pedal (on the Sit-Down cabinet). The first objective of the game is to finish the qualifying lap as quickly as possible. If the driver beats the time
column7: he qualifies for the race. If he does not qualify
column8: he drives the remainder of his time along the qualifying course.[-LF-]As a qualifier
column9: the driver is ranked according to his qualifying lap time
column10: from position one (the pole position) to position eight. Then the driver's second objective is to race against the clock and other cars to finish the race laps as fast as possible
column11: and to achieve the highest score possible. The driver earns points for passing cars
column12: driving on the track
column13: and finishing the race with time remaining. The time remaining from the Racing Lap is added to the extended lap time.[-LF-]To start the Play Mode
column14: a driver must first insert the correct number of coin(s) for a game (according to the coin dip switch settings
column15: 1 coin/1 credit is the default for both 'Coin A' and 'Coin B' dips). Then the driver turns the steering wheel until the track he wants to drive on is highlighted in white. The Play Mode will begin when the driver steps on the accelerator. The driver's car will appear behind the starting line and a certain amount of time
column16: in seconds ('Game Time' dip switch setting; the default is 90 seconds) will be on the clock. The car must finish the qualifying lap within the time allotted to be in the race. If the driver does not qualify
column17: his car continues on the track until the 'Game Time' elapses.[-LF-]If the driver has qualified
column18: just before the race begins
column19: the driver's car (flashing on the screen) is placed at the starting line with seven other cars. The position of the car depends on the position earned during the qualifying lap.[-LF-]The starting lights flash from red to green
column20: and the race begins. Racing hazards are other racing cars
column21: sharp turns
column22: water puddles
column23: and road signs (all of these hazards also appear during the qualifying lap with the exception of water puddles). As the race progresses
column24: more cars appear on the track. If the driver's car hits another car or a road sign
column25: the driver's car is destroyed in an explosion. (Pole Position II adds flying debris to the visual effect.) The driver's car reappears in a few seconds and the race continues. Driving through water puddles or off the track slows down the driver's car considerably.[-LF-]Experience will teach a driver which turns on which tracks require slight steering (because they're banked) and which turns require fast and forceful steering. He jockeys for position with the other racers
column26: while keeping his eye on the clock at the top of the screen. When his time runs out
column27: the race is over. If he has beaten the racing lap time and has seconds remaining
column28: the remaining seconds are added to the extended lap time
column29: which varies depending on the track and the 'Extended Rank' dip switch setting.[-LF-]The top score achieved by a driver appears at the top of the screen. The time allotted for the lap is displayed under the top score. Increasing lap time (in seconds and hundredths of a second) and the speed of the car appears last. Each track has its own separate high score list.

column1: pong>Pong>Atari>Atari>1972>Ball & Paddle>AAMA - Green (Suitable For All Ages)>1-2 Players>3.2>Pong (marketed as PONG) is one of the earliest arcade video games and the very first sports arcade video game. It is a tennis sports game featuring simple two-dimensional graphics. While other arcade video games such as Computer Space came before it
column2: Pong was one of the first video games to reach mainstream popularity. The aim is to defeat an opponent in a simulated table-tennis game by earning a higher score. The game was originally manufactured by Atari Incorporated (Atari)
column3: which released it in 1972. Allan Alcorn created Pong as a training exercise assigned to him by Atari co-founder Nolan Bushnell. Bushnell based the idea on an electronic ping-pong game included in the Magnavox Odyssey
column4: which later resulted in a lawsuit against Atari. Surprised by the quality of Alcorn's work
column5: Bushnell and Atari co-founder Ted Dabney decided to manufacture the game.Pong quickly became a success and is the first commercially successful arcade video game machine
column6: which helped to establish the video game industry along with the first home console
column7: the Magnavox Odyssey. Soon after its release
column8: several companies began producing games that copied Pong '​s gameplay
column9: and eventually released new types of games. As a result
column10: Atari encouraged its staff to produce more innovative games. The company released several sequels that built upon the original's gameplay by adding new features. During the 1975 Christmas season
column11: Atari released a home version of Pong exclusively through Sears retail stores. It was also a commercial success and led to numerous copies. The game has been remade on numerous home and portable platforms following its release. Pong has been referenced and parodied in multiple television shows and video games
column12: and has been a part of several video game and cultural exhibitions.>

relief>Relief Pitcher>Atari Games>Atari Games>1992>Sports/Baseball>AAMA - Green (Suitable For All Ages)>1-2 Players>2.8>Relief Pitcher is a 1992 baseball video game originally released for video arcades. Versions of the game were also released for the Atari Lynx and Super NES.Summary[edit]Arcade game endingThere are two modes to this game: players can either be the starting pitcher; which is a full 9-inning game for either one or two players or they can be the relief pitcher and do a 12-game season for one player only.An additional relief pitcher mode allows a best of 7 World Series type of play for two players.[2]There are four fictitious teams (Boston Bashers
column2: Houston Dusters
column3: Los Angeles Speeders
column4: and Chicago Strokers) to choose from with its own special strength.[2][3] Players must choose their favorite special pitch and dive into the more complicated mechanics of pitching a baseball. All the ballplayers in the game are fictional. There are many meters to use while determining whether to strike out the batter or give him an intentional walk instead. Batters also have to deal with meters that have to do with offense rather than defense.[2]After playing each game
column5: the player is entitled to a certain level of salary. This depends on how good the player performs out in the field. After winning the playoffs in arcade mode
column6: it shows the final box score with a special game over message inside of it.[4] The commentary in this game is done by legendary baseball announcer Jack Buck.[2]>

column2: which roughly translates to ""Hot-Blooded Tough Guy Kunio""[1])
column3: released earlier the same year by Technos. It is an immediate technological predecessor to Double Dragon
column4: and Nekketsu Kōha Kunio-kun is the inaugural game in the Kunio-kun series (which includes Super Dodge Ball and River City Ransom).Renegade first introduced several trademarks of the beat 'em up genre
column5: including 4-directional control
column6: punch-jump-kick play action
column7: and enemies which can sustain multiple hits. It is considered to be one of the most influential titles of the video game industry.[2][3]">

column1: ripoff>Rip Off>Cinematronics>Cinematronics>1980>Shoot-'Em-Up>AAMA - Green (Suitable For All Ages)>1-2 Players>3.9>"Rip-Off is a vector shoot 'em up released in arcades by Cinematronics in 1980. It is the first shoot 'em up arcade game to feature cooperative gameplay and the first game to exhibit ""flocking"" behavior. The objective is to prevent computer-controlled enemies from stealing eight canisters set in the center of the screen. One or two players control tank-like vehicles while game-controlled ""pirate"" tanks rush onto the field and attempt to drag the canisters off the edge of the screen. Enemies can be defeated by shooting or colliding with them. The game speed and difficulty increase with each successive wave until all the canisters have been taken (""ripped off"").">
